title: $1.4b pulled from HK hedge funds
text:
Hong Kong | Hong Kong's hedge fund industry saw its biggest quarterly outflow since the global recession a decade ago, a shift that may deepen concern about investor sentiment in the protest-wracked financial hub.

Net redemptions totaled about $US1 billion ($1.4 billion) in the three months ended September, the most since the second quarter of 2009, according to data compiled by Eurekahedge.

Analysts from the research firm said that while anti-government protests in Hong Kong have unnerved markets, the outflow was in keeping with redemptions from hedge funds globally after poor returns from a number of managers in 2018.

The withdrawals from Hong Kong were modest relative to total hedge fund assets in the city, which climbed $US6.9 billion ($10.1 billion) this year to $US92 billion ($134 billion) as of August thanks largely to positive market returns, according to Eurekahedge.

Small-and medium-sized hedge funds managing US$500 million ($732 million) or less accounted for the bulk of client outflows, with bigger funds seeing positive allocations, the research firm said. The industry has enjoyed net annual inflows every year since 2009.
description: It's the biggest quarterly outflow of funds for 10 years as Hong Kong's protests for democracy continue to trouble investors.
